articles.headline: Guantánamo Trials Grapple With How Much Evidence to Allow About Torture
articles.snippet: The military tribunals originally barred public mention of what happened at C.I.A. prisons. Now a key question is what evidence terrorism suspects can use as the cases inch forward.
articles.abstract: The military tribunals originally barred public mention of what happened at C.I.A. prisons. Now a key question is what evidence terrorism suspects can use as the cases inch forward.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.

articles.headline: Lil Nas X Added Billy Ray Cyrus to ‘Old Town Road.’ Is It Country Enough for Billboard Now?
articles.snippet: After a song that melds hip-hop and country was booted from the trade publication’s Hot Country chart, Lil Nas made a countermove.
articles.abstract: After a song that melds hip-hop and country was booted from the trade publication’s Hot Country chart, Lil Nas made a countermove.
articles.lead_paragraph: Booming beats. A twanging banjo. Is this country music?

articles.headline: Boeing to Cut Production of 737 Max After 2 Fatal Crashes
articles.snippet: The company also announced it would create a new board committee to review the design and development of new airplanes.
articles.abstract: The company also announced it would create a new board committee to review the design and development of new airplanes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Boeing said on Friday that it was slowing production of its 737 Max jet and establishing a new internal safety committee after two of the planes were involved in fatal crashes in five months.

articles.headline: Trump Lawyer Asserts President’s Right to Keep Tax Returns Private
articles.snippet: The lawyer’s argument foreshadows a likely and far-reaching legal fight over President Trump’s tax returns that could wind up in the Supreme Court.
articles.abstract: The lawyer’s argument foreshadows a likely and far-reaching legal fight over President Trump’s tax returns that could wind up in the Supreme Court.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s personal lawyer on Friday asserted Mr. Trump’s right as a citizen to keep his tax returns private and told the Treasury Department not to hand the returns over to House Democrats, foreshadowing what has the potential to be a far-reaching legal fight that could reach the Supreme Court.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Fandos and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: What the Rest of the World Can Learn From the Australian Economic Miracle
articles.snippet: As Americans worry about the potential end of a 10-year expansion, it’s worth studying the Aussies, whose winning streak is about to turn 28.
articles.abstract: As Americans worry about the potential end of a 10-year expansion, it’s worth studying the Aussies, whose winning streak is about to turn 28.
articles.lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — One Saturday in March, in the suburbs north of Sydney, around three dozen people gathered on a lawn outside a smallish two-bedroom apartment.

articles.headline: Why Scandinavian Banks’ Clean Reputations Are Threatened by Dirty Money
articles.snippet: Once known for prudence, Danske Bank and Swedbank are at the vortex of multifaceted money laundering scandals. Here’s how to make sense of them.
articles.abstract: Once known for prudence, Danske Bank and Swedbank are at the vortex of multifaceted money laundering scandals. Here’s how to make sense of them.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Scandinavia has long had a reputation as one of the most progressive regions in the world, known for generous parental leaves, bicycle superhighways and Abba.

articles.headline: Biden Didn’t Rush Into 2020. The Race Came to Him Anyway.
articles.snippet: Joe Biden delayed his entry into the Democratic field, hoping to avoid the fray. Now, a crisis he was unprepared for has left him as badly bruised as anyone in the race.
articles.abstract: Joe Biden delayed his entry into the Democratic field, hoping to avoid the fray. Now, a crisis he was unprepared for has left him as badly bruised as anyone in the race.
articles.lead_paragraph: For months, former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. hewed to a tortoise-like strategy for the 2020 presidential race: Repeatedly delaying his final decision, he hoped to skirt a long stretch of campaigning as a front-runner with a target on his back.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Fiery Deaths of 10 Boys Exposes Brutality of Brazil’s Soccer Mills
articles.snippet: Young players with dreams of glory think elite training programs lead to riches. They do. Just rarely for them.
articles.abstract: Young players with dreams of glory think elite training programs lead to riches. They do. Just rarely for them.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Even in death the haggling went on.
articles.byline: By Tariq Panja and Manuela Andreoni

articles.headline: In San Francisco, Making a Living From Your Billionaire Neighbor’s Trash
articles.snippet: In a city swollen by the wealth of the tech industry, the rich and poor live very separate lives. But sometimes they connect through the garbage.
articles.abstract: In a city swollen by the wealth of the tech industry, the rich and poor live very separate lives. But sometimes they connect through the garbage.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Three blocks from Mark Zuckerberg’s $10 million Tudor home in San Francisco, Jake Orta lives in a small, single-window studio apartment filled with trash.

articles.headline: Is the U.S. a Democracy? A Social Studies Battle Turns on the Nation’s Values
articles.snippet: Michigan spent five years debating how to teach American history. One of the biggest questions was how to describe the nation’s government.
articles.abstract: Michigan spent five years debating how to teach American history. One of the biggest questions was how to describe the nation’s government.
articles.lead_paragraph: LANSING, Mich. — Bruising political fights are usual business in Becky Debowski’s eighth-grade social studies classroom. From a model Constitutional Convention to a bare-knuckle debate in Congress over slavery, she regularly has students assume roles of partisans throughout American history, like Abraham Lincoln and John C. Calhoun.

articles.headline: Blamed for Climate Change, Oil Companies Invest in Carbon Removal
articles.snippet: Chevron, Occidental Petroleum and BHP have invested in Carbon Engineering, a start-up developing technology to take carbon out of the atmosphere.
articles.abstract: Chevron, Occidental Petroleum and BHP have invested in Carbon Engineering, a start-up developing technology to take carbon out of the atmosphere.
articles.lead_paragraph: SQUAMISH, British Columbia — Everyone knows an electric fan can make people feel cooler on a steamy day. But could fans moderate the planet’s rising temperatures?

articles.headline: The Hottest App in China Teaches Citizens About Their Leader — and, Yes, There’s a Test
articles.snippet: Millions of Chinese are using the app as part of President Xi’s efforts to strengthen ideological control in the digital age. Critics say it fuels a personality cult.
articles.abstract: Millions of Chinese are using the app as part of President Xi’s efforts to strengthen ideological control in the digital age. Critics say it fuels a personality cult.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHANGSHA, China — Inside a fishing gear store on a busy city street, the owner sits behind a counter, furiously tapping a smartphone to improve his score on an app that has nothing to do with rods, reels and bait.

articles.headline: $3,000 to Rent a Movie? Bringing the Theater Home for the 1 Percent
articles.snippet: Red Carpet Home Cinema offers Hollywood’s latest movies, but it’s not cheap for customers to rent films still in the theaters.
articles.abstract: Red Carpet Home Cinema offers Hollywood’s latest movies, but it’s not cheap for customers to rent films still in the theaters.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — Fred Rosen, the retired Ticketmaster tycoon, was eating a melted ham-and-brie sandwich at the exclusive San Vicente Bungalows and spouting forth about belts.

articles.headline: Hunger and an ‘Abandoned’ Hospital: Puerto Rico Waits as Washington Bickers
articles.snippet: A languishing island hospital and expired food aid are some of the signs that rebuilding has stagnated nearly a year and a half after Hurricane Maria devastated Puerto Rico.
articles.abstract: A languishing island hospital and expired food aid are some of the signs that rebuilding has stagnated nearly a year and a half after Hurricane Maria devastated Puerto Rico.
articles.lead_paragraph: VIEQUES, P.R. — A newborn’s cries rarely echo anymore though the hallways of what passes as a hospital on the ravaged island of Vieques, off the coast of Puerto Rico.

articles.headline: As Netanyahu Seeks Re-election, the Future of the West Bank Is Now on the Ballot
articles.snippet: Fighting for political survival, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu backed extending sovereignty over the West Bank, putting a contentious issue front and center.
articles.abstract: Fighting for political survival, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu backed extending sovereignty over the West Bank, putting a contentious issue front and center.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — As Israelis get ready to go to the polls on Tuesday, a stark, fateful and long-deferred choice has suddenly reappeared to confront them after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s unexpected promise to begin extending sovereignty over the West Bank if he is re-elected.

articles.headline: Kirstjen Nielsen Resigns as Trump’s Homeland Security Secretary
articles.snippet: The president had blamed Ms. Nielsen for the rise in migrants who illegally entered the United States even though she supported his hard-line immigration policies.
articles.abstract: The president had blamed Ms. Nielsen for the rise in migrants who illegally entered the United States even though she supported his hard-line immigration policies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Kirstjen Nielsen, the homeland security secretary, resigned on Sunday after meeting with President Trump, ending a tumultuous tenure in charge of the border security agency that had made her the target of the president’s criticism.
articles.byline: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Maggie Haberman, Michael D. Shear and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Pinterest Dials Down Expectations as I.P.O. Nears
articles.snippet: The digital pin board company set a price range for its I.P.O. that would value the business below its last private market valuation of $12 billion.
articles.abstract: The digital pin board company set a price range for its I.P.O. that would value the business below its last private market valuation of $12 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Pinterest set a price range for its initial public offering that will value the company below its last private-market peg of $12 billion, raising questions about investor demand for prominent but unprofitable technology companies that are stampeding toward the stock market.
articles.byline: By Erin Griffith and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Trump Designates Iran’s Revolutionary Guards a Foreign Terrorist Group
articles.snippet: The designation is the first one by the United States against part of a foreign government. The Pentagon and C.I.A. oppose the move, citing risks to Americans.
articles.abstract: The designation is the first one by the United States against part of a foreign government. The Pentagon and C.I.A. oppose the move, citing risks to Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Monday that he was designating a powerful arm of the Iranian military as a foreign terrorist organization, the first time that the United States has named part of another nation’s government as that type of official threat.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong and Eric Schmitt
